Lab Exercise 1: Basic Inputs and Outputs

The Preamble

Welcome to digital design with the Arduino! Arduino is a microcontroller excellent for small electronics projects. In the past, Arduino’s have nestled themselves into projects from blinking LEDs to flying quadcopters. Like other microcontrollers, the Arduino is best at sending and receiving electrical signals. With this ability, you, the designer, can interact with the world by driving signals to turn on lights, motors, sounds, based on the sensory input around you.

Important: The Lab Format

These Labs are formatted into two partitions: a tutorial and a deliverable. The tutorials are designed to give you one or more fundamental skills for the week. The deliverable is your way of demonstrating that you can create a project based on the tutorial we’ve provided for you. You aren’t required to complete the tutorial, but you must turn in the deliverable. Many of the tutorials will involve creating a lot of hardware on a breadboard; thus, to save you time, the deliverable will derive itself from a very similar circuit. Unless you're strongly familiar with the Arduino Programming Language already, we highly recommend that you work through the tutorial. Along the way, we’ll also provide you with helpful references to further your knowledge in the related section.

1. Digital Output: Blinking that LED

Two Design Aspects

The Hardware

Breadboard Basics

Take a look at your breadboard's hole pattern. Breadboards are designed to have each of their inner rows electrically connected, and to have each of their outer columns electrically connected. Thus, by plugging a component into a row, you create 4 additional places to connect from it. To illustrate this concept, we've covered each distinct electrical connection with a blue wire in the picture below.

In general, the red columns will be used for power supplies and the black columns will be used as a common ground connection. In this manner, you can easily bring power and ground to any location on your breadboard.

2. Digital Input: Adding a Push-Button

For digital input, we'll add a push-button. This push-button is a momentary-on push-button, which means that the circuit will be closed (connected) when the button is pushed and open (not connected) when the button is released. Modify your circuit below by adding a push-button. Notice that we're creating a separate loop from power to ground. The Arduino watches the voltage level just below the pin with the newly-added white wire.

A push-button provides digital input (either on or off) that the Arduino can detect. To do so, we'll call upon the digitalRead function.

Take a look at the function's documentation, and copy-and-paste the example code into a blank Arduino sketch window. Change pin 13 to pin 2 and, upload the code, and give it a run!

3. Analog Output: Pulsing an LED

The Gritty Reality: no real analog output

Alas, the reality of the Digital World is that the Arduino, a digital device, can't produce true analog values as outputs. In other words, you can't change the brightness of an LED by gradually increasing and decreasing the voltage on the Arduino pin smoothly from 0 to 5 [V]. You can either turn it fully-on (5 [V]) or fully-off (0 [V]).

Luckily, we can fake it. For some applications, we can create pseudo-analog voltages by simply turning on and off the Arduino pin very quickly with a pulse train. By varying how long we keep the Arduino pin on per pulse, we can make the LED appear brighter or darker because your eye integrates the light. Luckily, this rapid pulsing of the pin is taken care of by Arduino's analogWrite function.

Let's open another example from File --> Examples --> Analog --> Fading . Also: change the LED pin to pin 9 on the Arduino board. Now upload the code and watch the LED fade.

The good news is that you can quite easily simulate a blinking LED, and with some code tweaks, you can create a "breathing" LED. The bad news is that the analogWrite function doesn't work on every pin. Take a look at its documentation before creating your project.

4. Serial Communication

Lastly, let's talk about communication between the computer and the Arduino. The Arduino's chip has built-in hardware that can communicate with the computer. To use it, we call the Arduino's Serial functions.
At a slightly deeper level, the Arduino and computer communicate with each other by sending bytes of data to each other. Very often, we'll want to send over data encoded as text; to do this, we often use the char datatype. A char is simply a number that represents a particular keyboard character using an encoding called ASCII. To send chars across the serial line to the computer, you use the Serial.println function.

Let's begin by plugging your Arduino back in and uploading another example. Copy-and-paste the example here.

Watch out for a brief note of confusion! It turns out that the keyboard number keys can also be encoded as 'chars.' If you perform math on this char representation of a number, though, you'll actually be performing math on the numerical encoding of that number. To keep things straight, you'll want to convert your numbers encoded as chars to be their actual numerical counterparts. Luckily, for the chars 0 through 9, you just need to subtract 48. If this seems confusing, have a look at the ASCII encoding of those numbers, which are entries 48 through 57 in this table. So why is this important? It turns out that the computer defaults to sending the "char" representation of a number over to the Arduino via the serial monitor window. Thus, you'll have to decrypt it to get the actual number that you want.

For a slightly more thorough understanding of Serial Communication, feel free to check out Lada Ada's Tutorial over from Adafruit.
